{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16523,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ilex coriacea, also known as large gallberry, prefers consistently moist soil, reflecting its natural swampy habitat. Watering should be regular but not excessive; the soil should remain damp but not waterlogged. In well-draining soil, plan to water about once a week, making adjustments for rainfall. During hot, dry periods, increase watering to keep the roots moist. Be cautious in containers, as pots dry out faster. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency, mimicking the plant's natural environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ilex coriacea thrives in partial shade to full sun. It prefers dappled sunlight or light shade similar to its native swamp habitats. Although it can adapt to full sun exposure, ensure adequate moisture is maintained, especially in hotter regions. In its preferred lighting, the plant will have vibrant foliage and healthy growth. If planted in very shaded areas, growth may be slower and less vigorous. When introducing to a sunnier spot, acclimate gradually to prevent leaf scorch. Overall, this plant is quite adaptable but performs best with some protection from intense afternoon sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Ilex coriacea to maintain its shape, control size, and encourage bushier growth. Early spring is the best time for pruning before new growth starts. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Cut back leggy stems to promote a denser appearance, trimming just above a leaf node or lateral branch. Avoid drastic pruning in a single session; instead, gradually shape the plant over several seasons. This species tolerates pruning well; however, ensure tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease. Minimal pruning is required once the desired shape and size are achieved."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large Gallberry","description":"Ilex coriacea, sometimes known as large gallberry, is a shrub in the Holly family native to coastal areas in the United States from Virginia to Texas. It exists primarily as an understory plant in pine forests, and is sometimes stimulated by regular controlled burnings.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Large Gallberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Ilex coriacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17813,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plectranthus amboinicus, commonly known as Cuban Oregano, prefers moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot, as the plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. Water the plant thoroughly, and ensure good drainage by using a well-draining soil mix. During the growing season, water more frequently when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In winter, reduce watering as the plant’s growth slows down. Overwatering can lead to waterlogged soil and root damage, so always check soil moisture levels before watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plectranthus amboinicus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, place the plant where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorching. If grown indoors, a south or west-facing window with filtered light is suitable. While it can handle some direct sun, too much intense, direct exposure can harm the plant. If the leaves begin to pale or develop brown spots, consider adjusting the light conditions to a shadier location. Regularly turning the plant helps ensure even growth and prevents it from leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning helps maintain the compact and bushy shape of Plectranthus amboinicus. Prune every few months by pinching back the stems to encourage branching and more foliage production. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems to keep the plant healthy. Keeping the plant well-pruned not only promotes fullness but also prevents it from becoming leggy. Pruning can also be done selectively to control the plant size, especially if it’s being grown in a container indoors. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cuban oregano","description":"Plectranthus amboinicus, once identified as Coleus amboinicus, is a semi-succulent perennial plant in the family Lamiaceae with a pungent oregano-like flavor and odor. It is native to Southern and Eastern Africa. It is widely cultivated and naturalized elsewhere in the tropics where it is used as a traditional medicine, spice, and ornamental plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa","Asia"],"other_name":["Cuban oregano"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Plectranthus amboinicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16723,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Omalotheca sylvatica, commonly known as woodland cudweed, prefers soil that remains consistently moist but never waterlogged. To care for this plant, water it moderately, ensuring the soil doesn't completely dry out between watering sessions. Check the top inch of soil, and if it feels dry, it's time to water again. Adjust the frequency based on seasonal variations, reducing during winter months when growth tends to slow down. Avoid overhead watering to prevent leaf diseases. Maintaining this balance will help preserve the plant's health and vitality, accommodating its natural environment preferences."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Omalotheca sylvatica thrives in conditions that mimic its natural woodland habitat. It's best grown in partial to full shade where it can receive dappled sunlight throughout the day. Too much direct sunlight can damage its leaves, causing them to scorch, while overly shady conditions might inhibit its growth. An area that receives morning sun and afternoon shade is ideal. If you're growing this plant indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window to achieve the right sunlight balance. Adjust as necessary depending on the specific environment and season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Omalotheca sylvatica is relatively simple and revolves around maintaining its aesthetic and promoting growth. Trim back any dead or damaged leaves and stems with a sharp pair of garden shears to improve air circulation and prevent disease. During its growing season, pruning is minimal except for cleaning up any faded blooms to encourage additional flowering. At the end of the growing period, a more thorough pruning can be conducted to tidy up the plant before winter dormancy. Always sanitize your pruning tools before and after use to prevent the spread of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Woodland Cudweed","description":"Omalotheca sylvatica, also called woodland arctic cudweed, is a species of plant from Asteraceae family that can be found in Eastern United States and British Columbia, on the lawns, roads, and in the forests. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist without allowing it to become waterlogged. An ideal watering schedule would ensure the soil is kept damp but not overly saturated. In particularly hot and dry weather conditions, you may need to increase the frequency of watering to help maintain its moisture levels. However, always check the soil moisture before watering to avoid root rot and ensure that the plant has adequate drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physostegia pulchella thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote lush growth and abundant flowering. However, in regions with very hot and intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching and excessive drying. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may result in fewer flowers and a less vigorous growth habit. It's important to experiment with the best placement in your garden to maximize its sun exposure while protecting it from harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Physostegia pulchella involves removing spent blooms and dead foliage to encourage continuous blooming and healthy growth. After the plant finishes flowering, you should cut back flower stalks to the base, which will promote new growth and potentially a second wave of flowers. During the growing season, regularly checking for and removing any dead or damaged leaves will help maintain the plant’s appearance and overall health. Additionally, in late autumn, cutting the plant back to the ground prepares it for winter dormancy, ensuring vigorous growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beautiful False Dragon's Head","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Beautiful False Dragon's Head"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Physostegia pulchella"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best suited for a sunny spot in the garden where it can fully bask in direct sunlight throughout the peak hours of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sphaeralcea hastulata involves removing dead or damaged stems, which can be done in late winter or early spring before the plant begins its new growth cycle. During its growing season, typically from spring to late summer, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. In the winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering significantly, sometimes only watering monthly or not at all depending on the humidity levels in your environment. Always use a pot with drainage holes and a well-draining soil mix, such as a cactus or succulent mix, to ensure excess water does not accumulate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This cactus enjoys plenty of sunlight and should be placed in a location where it can receive full sun for several hours a day. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window is optimal. If it starts to stretch or become etiolated, it's likely a sign that it's not getting enough light. Ensure gradual acclimatization if increasing light exposure to avoid shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mammillaria polythele generally requires little pruning. However, you can maintain its health and shape by removing any dead or damaged parts. This is best done with clean, sharp tools to avoid disease transmission. If the plant develops offsets or pups that you wish to remove, wait until they are large enough to handle, then gently twist them away from the main plant. This can encourage the main plant to grow more actively and can also allow you to propagate new plants. Ensure that any wounds created during pruning are allowed to callus over to prevent infection."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":"Mammillaria polythele is a cactus in the genus Mammillaria, in Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria polythele"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you're growing this plant indoors or in a less sunny spot, consider supplementing with artificial lights during shorter days to ensure it receives adequate light for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bromus pubescens involves removing any dead or damaged foliage, which not only helps to maintain the plant's appearance but also promotes healthy growth. It's crucial to avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot, especially since it is adapted to well-drained conditions. During the growing season in the spring, water when the soil begins to dry out, ensuring that the medium is consistently but not excessively moist. In its dormant period during the summer, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to rest. Direct, harsh sunlight can be damaging, especially if the plant is exposed for prolonged periods. Ideally, place it where it receives filtered light, such as near a window with a sheer curtain, or in a spot that only gets a few hours of direct morning or late afternoon sun. This balance allows the plant to photosynthesize without risking leaf scorch, promoting healthy growth and vibrant flowering. Indoor growers may consider supplemental lighting during darker months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ophrys fusca is minimal and typically involves removing spent flowers and dead foliage to encourage the plant to concentrate energy on new growth. After the flowering period, it's helpful to cut back the flower spike at its base, which can often promote the plant's health for the next season. Be sure to use sterilized pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease. In its dormant phase, further pruning is unnecessary; allow the plant to naturally die back, which is a part of its lifecycle. Regular cleaning of dead material can help prevent pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sombre Bee-orchid","description":"Ophrys fusca, commonly known as the sombre bee-orchid or the dark bee-orchid, is a species of orchid native to the Mediterranean from southwestern Europe and northern Africa to western Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","Europe"],"other_name":["Sombre Bee-orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ophrys fusca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Alkaline","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning in late summer or fall, as this can reduce flowering the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Bridal-wreath","description":"Spiraea prunifolia, commonly called bridalwreath spirea, is a species of the genus Spiraea, sometimes also spelled Spirea. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17716,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mammilloydia candida, commonly known as the Snowball Cactus, requires careful watering. During its active growing season in the spring and summer, water the cactus thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering in the fall and keep the soil mostly dry through the winter months. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage. It's better to underwater than overwater, especially in cooler temperatures. Always adjust watering frequency based on humidity and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This cactus enjoys full sun exposure. Ideally, Mammilloydia candida should be placed in a location where it can receive bright, direct sunlight for at least 6 hours a day. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can get sufficient light. Gradually acclimate the cactus to full sun if it has been in lower light conditions to prevent sunburn. During the hottest summer months, some afternoon shade can help prevent overheating and sun damage, while in winter, maintain its access to ample light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Mammilloydia candida is generally minimal and only necessary to remove damaged or diseased parts of the cactus. Since it's a thistle, it can be invasive if left unchecked. Regular deadheading of flowers can minimize seed production and self-seeding. Use gloves and long sleeves when pruning to protect yourself from its spiny stems. At the end of the growing season, cut back the plant to ground level to encourage healthy regrowth and reduce pest infestations. Pruning also helps in managing its growth if being kept in a controlled garden space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Welted Thistle","description":"Carduus crispus, the curly plumeless thistle or welted thistle, is a biennial herb in the daisy family Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16326,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinacea sanguinea, commonly known as the Pale Purple Coneflower, requires moderate watering once established. Initially, when the plant is newly planted, it is essential to water it regularly to help it establish a strong root system. However, once established, Echinacea sanguinea is drought-tolerant and requires less frequent watering. Water the plant deeply once the top 1-2 inches of soil is dry, usually once a week during dry periods. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinacea sanguinea thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. The plant can tolerate partial shade, but for optimal blooming and growth, full sun is recommended. In areas with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent stress on the plant. Ensure it is planted in an area where it receives adequate sun exposure to maintain its health and vibrant blooms. Consistent sunlight helps the plant develop strong stems and produce a profusion of flowers throughout the blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Echinacea sanguinea involves removing spent blooms and dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth and a tidy appearance. Deadheading, or removing faded flowers, encourages the plant to produce more blooms and extends the flowering season. Use clean, sharp shears to cut the stem back to the nearest set of leaves. In late fall or early spring, cut back the entire plant to about six inches above the ground to remove any dead stems and prepare it for new growth. This will help rejuvenate the plant and improve its overall vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sanguine purple coneflower","description":"Echinacea sanguinea (sanguine purple coneflower) is a herbaceous perennial native to open sandy fields and open pine woods and prairies in eastern Texas, southeastern Oklahoma, Louisiana, and southwestern Arkansas. It is the southernmost Echinacea species. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17122,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia radiata, a carnivorous aquatic plant, requires environments mimicking its natural habitat – boggy, wet, and nutrient-poor waters. In cultivation, maintain its substrate in continuously moist to waterlogged conditions. Ensure that the water is low in dissolved minerals and nutrients, similar to rainwater, distilled, or reverse osmosis water, avoiding tap water that might contain high mineral content. Regularly check the moisture levels to consistently keep the soil or substrate saturated, as drying out can be detrimental to its health. Remember, the key is to mimic the bog-like conditions, providing standing water around the plants for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia radiata thrives in bright, indirect light, akin to the conditions found in its natural icy swamps and bogs under partial sun exposure. This plant does well in full sun to partial shade, but avoid harsh, direct midday sunlight which can cause scorching. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of light daily, with some shade during the hottest parts of the day. If grown indoors, place it near a well-lit window, perhaps with some filtered light. Outdoors, situate it where it can benefit from morning sunlight and dappled light in the afternoon."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Utricularia radiata is minimal as it naturally grows in water, often allowing decomposing parts to return nutrients to the environment. However, you can remove dead or decaying leaves and stems periodically to maintain aesthetics and prevent them from fouling the water, which can lead to poor oxygen conditions. Prune with care, using sterile scissors to avoid introducing pathogens. Regularly check for any unwanted algae growth or competing plants, removing them to prevent overcrowding and ensure that Utricularia radiata has ample space to thrive in its aquatic setting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Small Swollen Bladderwort","description":"Utricularia radiata, the little floating bladderwort, is a medium-sized suspended aquatic carnivorous plant that belongs to the genus Utricularia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17914,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Swietenia humilis, commonly known as Pacific Coast mahogany, prefers well-drained soils and can tolerate some drought once established. It is important to let the top few inches of soil dry out between waterings to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to this tropical tree. During the first few years of growth, regular watering is essential to help establish a deep root system, particularly in drier seasons. In general, watering should be reduced during the winter months when the tree is not actively growing. Always adjust watering frequency based on local rainfall and humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Swietenia humilis thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. It can tolerate partial shade, but insufficient sunlight may result in slower growth and less robust foliage. Planting in an open area where it can receive unobstructed sunlight will encourage a healthy, well-shaped tree. While young, small amounts of shading during the hottest part of the day can be beneficial to protect the leaves from sunburn, but as the tree matures, it becomes more tolerant of intense sunlight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Swietenia humilis is not routinely necessary but can be done to shape the tree and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. The best time for pruning is in late winter or early spring before the tree begins active growth. Removing lower branches can help train the tree to a single trunk, which is desirable for ornamental purposes. Ensure all cuts are clean and made at a slight angle to promote quick healing. Regularly removing suckers from the base can also help maintain the tree's shape and focus growth on the main trunk."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Honduras Mahogany","description":"Swietenia humilis is a species of tree in the family Meliaceae. It is one of three species in the genus Swietenia, all three of which are regarded as \"genuine mahogany.\" At 6 metres (20 ft), it is one-fifth the height of S. mahagoni and one-sixth the height of S. macrophylla. Its species name, humilis, means \"small\" or \"dwarfish\".","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Central America","Mexico"],"other_name":["Honduras Mahogany"],"pest_susceptibility":["Heart rot","Stem borer insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Swietenia humilis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17023,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiranthes ochroleuca requires a moderate amount of watering. It prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil, similar to its native habitat of moist meadows or woodland margins. It’s crucial to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During active growth in spring and summer, check the soil regularly and water when the top 1-2 inches feel dry. Reduce watering in fall and winter when the plant is dormant, allowing the topsoil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent excess moisture. Using distilled or rainwater is recommended if your tap water is particularly hard or chlorinated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiranthes ochroleuca thrives best in locations where it can receive partial sunlight exposure. It naturally grows in habitats with dappled sunlight under the canopy of trees, so mimic these conditions by providing it with morning sun and afternoon shade, or filtered sunlight throughout the day. Full sun exposure can be tolerated, but it requires careful monitoring of soil moisture to prevent drying out. On the other hand, too much shade may result in poor flowering and leggy growth. Finding a balance between light and shade is key to ensuring vigorous growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spiranthes ochroleuca is minimal and mostly involves removing spent flower spikes and dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health. Once the flowering season is over, typically late summer to early fall, cut back the flower spikes to the base to prevent any unnecessary energy expenditure on seed production, unless you wish to collect seeds. As leaves die back naturally during dormancy, these can also be carefully removed. Regular cleaning helps to reduce disease risk and keeps the plant looking tidy. Avoid heavy pruning which can stress the plant unnecessarily and disrupt its natural cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow nodding ladies' tresses","description":"Spiranthes ochroleuca, commonly called the yellow nodding lady's tresses, is a species of orchid occurring from southeastern Canada to the eastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["yellow nodding ladies' tresses"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Spiranthes ochroleuca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17421,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gloeoporus dichrous is a type of bracket fungus that generally grows on dead or decaying wood, which means it has adapted to growing in conditions where moisture levels can fluctuate. If you're cultivating this fungus, aim to keep the growing substrate (such as a wood log) slightly damp, similar to its natural environment in the wild. However, avoid waterlogging as excess moisture can lead to unfavorable conditions or other fungal growth. Regular misting may help, particularly in dry climates or during periods of low humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gloeoporus dichrous typically grows in shaded, damp woodland environments. It prefers indirect light conditions, so if you're cultivating it, choose a location that mimics these natural settings. Direct sunlight should generally be avoided as it can dry out the fungus and substrate, leading to a less favorable growth environment. Instead, opt for dappled sunlight or light filtered through a canopy or shade cloth. Keeping the fungus in a naturally humid and shaded area will help simulate its native habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a bracket fungus, Gloeoporus dichrous does not require traditional pruning like plants. Instead, care involves maintaining a conducive environment for its growth and managing any competing fungi or contaminants. If growing on a log, ensure that no unwanted fungi are taking over by carefully removing them. Additionally, older growths that are no longer vibrant can be trimmed away to allow for healthier, new growths. Always use sanitized tools to prevent any infections or unwanted spores from spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bicoloured bracket","description":"Gloeoporus dichrous is a species of fungus in the family Meruliaceae. First described as Polyporus dichrous by Elias Magnus Fries in 1815, it was later transferred to the genus Gloeoporus by Italian mycologist Giacomo Bresadola in 1912. The variety G. dichrous var. niger (formerly known as Ceriporiopsis nigra) was proposed in 2008 after molecular analysis revealed the two taxa were conspecific.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["bicoloured bracket"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Gloeoporus dichrous"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

It thrives best in consistently damp soil, so regular watering is recommended, especially in hot, dry periods. However, it's important to ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. It's advisable to monitor the moisture level of the soil and water whenever the top inch feels dry, ensuring the plant retains its vibrant green foliage and remains healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex albursina thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for shaded garden areas. While it can tolerate some morning sun, prolonged exposure to direct sunlight can cause the leaves to scorch and dry out, leading to poor growth and aesthetic appeal. Ideally, this plant should be situated in a location where it receives dappled sunlight or remains in the shadow of larger plants or trees. Ensuring it is shielded from harsh midday and afternoon sun will help it maintain its lush, green foliage and robust health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex albursina is fairly straightforward and primarily involves managing its appearance and promoting healthy growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged foliage by cutting it at the base. Occasionally thinning out the old shoots can help stimulate new growth and maintain an attractive clump shape. Avoid cutting the plant down completely as it can harm the overall health. Consistent, light pruning rather than drastic cuts will support its natural gracefulness and encourage lush growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Bear Sedge","description":"Carex albursina (White Bear sedge, blunt-scaled wood sedge) is a wide-leaved sedge. It grows in moist deciduous or mixed woods in eastern North America. It was named after White Bear Lake in east central Minnesota, where it was found by Edmund Sheldon in the 1890s. The leaves are 10–38 mm (3⁄8–1 1⁄2 inches) wide and 10–35 cm (4–14 inches) long.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["White Bear Sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Carex albursina"],"soil":["Loam","Sand"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The main aim is to remove dead or damaged leaves to maintain a neat appearance and health. Use sharp, clean tools to prune at the base of the leaf, avoiding any damage to the main stem. This agave occasionally produces offsets or \"pups,\" which can be removed if you wish to control the spread or propagate. Be cautious of the sharp leaf tips and consider wearing gloves to protect your hands during pruning. Regularly check for any signs of pests or disease, removing affected leaves as necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Century Plant","description":"Agave angustifolia (Caribbean agave) is a type of agave plant which is native to Mexico and Central America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17718,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocereus maritimus, a type of cactus, requires infrequent watering due to its drought-tolerant nature. During the active growing season, which is in spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly but let the soil dry completely between waterings. Typically, this would mean watering once every two to three weeks, but this can vary depending on your local climate and soil drainage. In winter, when the plant is dormant, reduce watering significantly—perhaps once a month—to prevent root rot. Always use pots with drainage holes and well-draining soil to keep the roots healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocereus maritimus thrives best in full sunlight, needing at least 6-8 hours of direct sun exposure daily. This makes a bright, south-facing window an ideal spot if grown indoors. Adequate sunlight ensures healthy growth and encourages blooming. If grown outdoors, mimic its natural habitat by choosing a location that receives ample sunlight. During extremely hot weather, some shade might be beneficial to prevent scorching. Without enough light, the plant may become elongated or etiolated, thus it's important to monitor and adjust the light exposure as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Echinocereus maritimus is generally minimal as it is a small, slow-growing cactus. Typically, you only need to prune if there are dead, damaged, or diseased parts on the cactus. Using sterilized scissors or a knife, carefully cut away these portions to prevent the spread of disease. Be careful with handling, as the cactus has spines that can prick. If the cactus begins to grow too tall or leggy, you may cut back sections to maintain its shape, but remove segments only from the top to encourage more lateral branching."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Fungal Infection"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Echinocereus maritimus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16327,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocactus horizonthalonius, commonly known as \"Devil's Head Cactus,\" requires careful watering to mimic its natural desert environment. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, water the cactus thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. This usually means watering every 2–3 weeks. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly to prevent root rot, as the plant enters dormancy. Overwatering can lead to root diseases, so it is crucial to ensure that the pot has excellent drainage and avoid letting the cactus sit in waterlogged soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocactus horizonthalonius thrives in bright, direct sunlight, consistent with its native desert habitat. Position the cactus in a south or west-facing window where it can receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. If growing outdoors, place it in a sunny spot with full sun exposure. Insufficient sunlight can lead to elongated growth and a loss of its natural shape. If natural sunlight is limited, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure it receives adequate light. Gradual exposure to increased light can help prevent sunburn on the cactus surface."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Echinocactus horizonthalonius is generally not necessary because it naturally grows into an attractive rounded shape. However, you may occasionally need to remove any dead or damaged parts to keep the plant healthy and looking its best. Use sterilized, sharp scissors or pruning tools to cut away any dead tissue, being careful not to damage the main body of the cactus. Take precautions such as wearing gloves to protect against its spines. Pruning should ideally be done during the plant’s growing season, allowing cuts to heal quicker."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Devilshead","description":"Echinocactus horizonthalonius is a species of cactus known by several common names, including devilshead, turk's head cactus, blue barrel cactus, eagle's claw, horse maimer, horse crippler, and visnaga meloncillo. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it occurs in Chihuahuan Desert and Sonoran Desert habitats, particularly on limestone substrates. One of its varieties is a federally listed endangered species of the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Devilshead"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Echinocactus horizonthalonius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant deeply once a week during dry spells and ensure a layer of mulch around the base to preserve soil moisture. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot, but ensure the plant does not dry out completely, especially during hot periods. Adjust watering frequency based on weather conditions, increasing during droughts and reducing during rainy seasons. Regularly check the soil moisture by inserting your finger about an inch deep; if it feels dry, it’s time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa bracteata thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Plant it in a location that receives adequate sunlight throughout the day for optimal blooming and vigor. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sunlight enhances flowering and overall growth. If planted in partial shade, ensure it receives morning sun to encourage blooms. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from the most intense midday sun, which might otherwise stress the plant or scorch its leaves. Ensure it has good air circulation to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa bracteata is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. Perform pruning in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing dead, diseased, or damaged canes to encourage air circulation and light penetration. Thin out crowded areas and shape the plant by cutting back to a healthy outward-facing bud. Reduce overly long canes to desired lengths to prevent them from becoming unruly. Regular pruning helps prevent the plant from taking over the garden as it can be quite vigorous. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Macartney's rose","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["Macartney's rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Black spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rosa bracteata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16625,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Malus angustifolia, commonly known as the Southern crabapple, requires moderate watering. This plant prefers well-drained soil and benefits from regular watering during dry periods, especially young trees. It's important not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. Allowing the top layer of soil to dry out between watering sessions is ideal. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering since the plant requires less moisture. Mulching can help retain soil moisture during hotter months and prevent competition with weeds."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Malus angustifolia thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to support healthy growth and abundant blooms. In full sun, the tree develops dense foliage and attractive flowers, which are critical for fruit production. While it can grow in partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced flowering and poorer fruit yield. Planting in an area with optimal sun exposure ensures the best health and growth outcomes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malus angustifolia should be done during the late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant. Focus on removing dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain good airflow and light penetration throughout the tree canopy. This helps in promoting healthy growth and reducing the risk of fungal infections. Light pruning each year helps control the shape and size of the tree, preventing it from becoming too dense. Avoid heavy pruning as it can reduce flowering and fruiting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"southern crabapple","description":"Malus angustifolia, or southern crabapple, is a species of crabapple native to the eastern and south-central United States from Florida west to eastern Texas and north to New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois and Missouri.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["southern crabapple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Apple scab","Fireblight","Cedar-apple rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Malus angustifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16825,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinguicula caerulea, commonly known as the blue butterwort, thrives in moist conditions. It is crucial to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. During the growing season, typically spring to fall, place the pot in a tray filled with distilled or rainwater to ensure constant moisture. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy, allowing the soil to slightly dry out between waterings, but not completely dry which could harm the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinguicula caerulea prefers bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so placing it near a north or east-facing window is ideal, where it can receive soft morning light but is shielded from harsh afternoon rays. If grown indoors, artificial grow lights can be used to supplement light, especially during shorter winter days. Aim for about 12-14 hours of light daily. The right balance of sunlight encourages healthy growth and prevents the leaves from becoming etiolated."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinguicula caerulea is minimal and primarily involves removing dead leaves and flowers to maintain its health and appearance. Gently pluck away any foliage or flowers that have turned brown or dried up, taking care not to damage the surrounding healthy tissue. This will promote air circulation and prevent decay. Caerulus is Latin for from the sky or sea and refers to the appearance of the leaves.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["blue butterwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Pinguicula caerulea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Peaty"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This orchid prefers its soil to be slightly moist, so ensure the soil is consistently damp but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, especially if planted in a pot or garden with poor drainage. It's essential to reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant, as the roots are susceptible to rot during this period. Always use well-draining soil to facilitate proper water flow."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiranthes tuberosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight to partial shade conditions. While it can handle full sun in cooler climates, it’s best to provide some shelter during the harsh midday sun, especially in areas with hot summers, to prevent leaf burn and stress. Placing the plant in dappled sunlight or under the canopy of larger trees can mimic its natural habitat and promote optimal growth. Ensuring the plant gets enough light is important for healthy blooms but avoid drastic changes in light conditions to prevent shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Spiranthes tuberosa is minimal and primarily involves cleaning up dead or spent foliage and flower stalks. After the blooming season, which is typically late summer to early autumn, cut back the flowering stems once they have browned and died back. Removing these spent parts helps direct the plant’s energy toward root and tuber development for the next season. Ensure to use sterilized pruning shears to prevent the spread of diseases. Regular maintenance can enhance the aesthetical appearance and health of the plant over time."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Little Ladies' Tresses","description":"Spiranthes tuberosa, common names little lady's tresses, little pearl-twist and slender ladies'-tresses is a perennial plant native to North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Little Ladies' Tresses"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Spiranthes tuberosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16229,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Condalia ericoides, commonly known as javelina bush or Brazilian bluewood, is a drought-tolerant plant native to arid regions. It prefers infrequent watering, ideally allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings to mimic its natural environment. During the growing season, it should be watered deeply but sparingly, approximately every 2 to 3 weeks. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In winter, watering should be reduced significantly, as the plant is dormant and requires minimal moisture. Always ensure the pot or soil has good drainage to prevent water accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Condalia ericoides thrives in full sunlight conditions, reflecting its native arid habitat. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to achieve optimal growth and flowering. Insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and sparse foliage. If growing indoors or in a less sunny location, try to position the plant near a south or west-facing window to maximize light exposure. For outdoor planting, choose a site that receives ample sunlight throughout the day. Full sun promotes healthy and vigorous growth, supporting its natural adaptation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Condalia ericoides is not routinely necessary but can be done to maintain shape or remove dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Carefully trim back any overgrown branches to encourage a more compact and bushy form, using clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission. If the plant is grown in a landscape setting, minimal pruning is required beyond regular maintenance and shaping. Sanitize the cutting tools before and after use to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"little buckthorn","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["little buckthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Condalia ericoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17422,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lentinus crinitus, being a type of fungus, typically does not require traditional watering like plants. Instead, maintaining a moist environment is important for its growth. If growing this mushroom for cultivation, ensure that the substrate remains moist by occasionally misting it with water. In natural settings, these fungi thrive in humid conditions found in their native habitats. Hence, maintaining ambient humidity through indirect misting or providing a humidifier can help achieve the right conditions. Avoid waterlogging or making the substrate overly wet as this can hinder the growth or promote unwanted bacterial growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lentinus crinitus, like many mushrooms, does not require direct sunlight as it thrives in shaded environments with diffuse light. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and negatively impact growth. Instead, aim for indirect lighting or keep the fungus in a naturally shaded area replicating its forest floor habitat. If indoors, placing the mushroom setup in a room with ambient, indirect light is sufficient. Artificial LED birthing lights mimicking natural light cycles can also be beneficial. Maintaining a stable temperature and humidity level alongside proper lighting conditions is crucial for the best growth results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not applicable for Lentinus crinitus as it is a mushroom rather than a plant. However, if you are cultivating this fungus, you can manage its growth by carefully removing mature fruiting bodies to make space for new ones. This can also prevent decay or attacks by pests on older, potentially decomposing mushrooms. Be gentle and use clean tools to avoid damaging the mycelium network or introducing contaminants into the environment which might affect subsequent growth. Monitoring and removing any contaminated mycelium blocks is advisable to maintain a healthy cultivation environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fringed sawgill","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["fringed sawgill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lentinus crinitus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16726,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Opuntia cochenillifera is a drought-tolerant cactus that requires minimal watering. Water it sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, which typically occurs in the spring and summer, water every 2–4 weeks, depending on the climate’s humidity and heat. In the fall and winter months, reduce watering to once every 4–6 weeks or even less, as the plant enters a dormant phase. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has excellent drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia cochenillifera thrives in full sunlight and prefers bright, direct light for at least 6 to 8 hours a day. Ideally, position the plant in a south-facing window or an outdoor location where it will receive ample sun exposure. While it can tolerate some partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in leggy growth and a pale coloration indicating poor health. In particularly hot climates, providing some light afternoon shade can prevent sunburn on the pads. Regular exposure to bright light is crucial to maintain vibrant growth and optimal health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia cochenillifera should be done mainly to remove any dead or damaged pads or to control its size and shape. The best time to prune is in early spring, before the growing season begins. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent the transmission of diseases. Always wear protective gloves to avoid injury from the pads' spines. Dispose of the pruned pads carefully, or propagate them if you wish to grow new plants. Minimal pruning is needed generally, as this species tends to maintain its shape well without much intervention."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cochineal Nopal Cactus","description":"Opuntia cochenillifera is a species of cactus in the subfamily Opuntioideae. It is endemic to Mexico. The first description was in 1753 by Carl Linnaeus as Cactus cochenillifer. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16104,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bryoandersonia illecebra, commonly known as \"worm moss,\" typically thrives in moist conditions. It is important to keep the substrate evenly moist but not waterlogged. During dry spells, regular watering is necessary to maintain optimal moisture levels, as drying out can be detrimental to the moss. However, in its natural habitat it often relies on natural rainfall, so if you are caring for it outdoors, less frequent watering might be needed. Indoors, ensure that the environment remains humid, which may involve misting the plant regularly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bryoandersonia illecebra thrives in dappled sunlight to partial shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. It does not handle direct sunlight well, as the intense rays can dry out and damage the moss. A location that receives indirect light or filtered sunlight is ideal. If grown indoors, placing it near a north-facing window or using sheer curtains can help provide the right amount of light. Outdoors, positioning it under tree canopies or in shaded garden areas will help it thrive while protecting it from harsh, direct sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bryoandersonia illecebra is not generally required as mosses like this typically maintain their shape and size naturally. After establishment, minimal watering is required, making it suitable for xeriscaping or areas with low rainfall. During particularly dry spells, occasional watering will help maintain its foliage, but overly frequent watering should be avoided to prevent potential root rot or fungal diseases from overly saturated soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex arenaria thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. If sunlight is limited indoors, consider supplementing with fluorescent grow lights, aiming for about 10-12 hours of light daily to keep the plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Palicourea padifolia is essential to encourage bushier growth and to maintain a desired shape. It is best to prune this plant in early spring before the new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves. Trim back overgrown branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. You can also pinch back the tips of the plant to promote branching, leading to a fuller appearance. Avoid excessive pruning at once, as this can stress the plant, and always clean tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Palicourea padifolia is a species from the genus Palicourea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Palicourea padifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If kept under artificial grow lights, provide at least 12-16 hours of light to mimic its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pinguicula lutea involves removing dead and decaying leaves to prevent mold and promote healthy growth. Use sterile scissors or tweezers to carefully snip away dead leaves, making sure to avoid damaging the plant's delicate roots and remaining healthy foliage. It's ideal to conduct this process during the plant's growing season when new growth is evident. Additionally, cleaning the leaves of any debris will keep the plant healthy and aid its carnivorous function. Minimal pruning is required, as Pinguicula lutea tends to maintain its own growth naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Butterwort","description":"Pinguicula lutea, commonly known as the yellow butterwort, is a species of warm-temperate carnivorous plant in the Lentibulariaceae family. Young trees need deep watering once a week if there's no rainfall, promoting deep root growth. Mature trees are more drought-tolerant but benefit from supplemental water during prolonged dry periods. It's important to ensure the soil drains well to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base helps retain moisture and reduces the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Malus baccata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and fruit production. Planting the tree in a location with full sun exposure ensures vigorous flowering and fruiting. Although it can tolerate partial shade, limited sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and fruit yield. Ensure that surrounding structures or vegetation do not overly shade the tree, allowing it to reach its full potential in terms of both size and fruit production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malus baccata should be done during late winter or early spring when the tree is still dormant. The primary goals are to maintain a healthy structure, remove dead or diseased branches, and encourage new growth. Start by cutting off any crossed or inward-growing branches, which can impede growth. Thinning out clusters of branches improves air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree, and ensure all cuts are clean to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian crabapple","description":"Malus baccata is an Asian species of apple known by the common names Siberian crab apple, Siberian crab, Manchurian crab apple and Chinese crab apple. It is native to much of northern Asia, but is also grown elsewhere as an ornamental tree and for rootstock. It is used for bonsai. It bears plentiful fragrant white flowers and edible red to yellow fruit of about 1 cm diameter.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Siberia"],"other_name":["Siberian crabapple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Apple scab","Fire blight","Cedar-apple rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Malus baccata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to water the plant deeply once to twice a week, depending on the weather and soil conditions. Ensure that the topsoil is dry before watering again to prevent root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture between waterings. Be cautious not to overhead water, as wet foliage can lead to diseases. Adjust watering frequency during dry spells or when the plant is actively blooming to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa majalis thrives best in full sun, which means it needs at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Planting it in an area with adequate sun exposure encourages robust blooming and strong growth. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. However, too much shade can lead to fewer flowers and leggier stems. Ensure that the planting site is open and not overshadowed by taller plants or structures to maximize sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa majalis should be done in late winter or early spring when the plant is still dormant. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to improve overall plant health. Next, thin out crowded areas to allow for better air circulation, which helps prevent fungal diseases. Aim to maintain an open center by cutting back any crossing branches. Pruning also encourages new growth; remove about one-third of the oldest stems down to the base of the plant annually to keep it rejuvenated and blooming vigorously."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cinnamon Rose","description":"Rosa majalis J. Herrm. (syn. R. cinnamomea sensu L. 1759, non 1753; R. cinnamomea auct. non L.; cinnamon rose; double cinnamon rose) is a species of deciduous shrubs in the genus Rosa, native to forests of Europe and Siberia. Watering should be done sparingly, allowing the soil to completely dry out between waterings. In the growing season, which is spring through summer, water once every 2-4 weeks, making sure the cactus is not sitting in water. During its dormant period in winter, significantly reduce watering, potentially only once a month or less, depending on your climate, to avoid overwatering which can cause root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia gosseliniana thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its health and vibrant color. It’s best to prune in the spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17025,"attracts":["Pollinators","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spondias purpurea, commonly known as the purple mombin or jocote, thrives in a variety of water conditions but prefers consistent moisture. In the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil moist, but ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can damage the roots. As the plant becomes established, it can tolerate drought conditions. During drier periods, increase watering frequency. However, avoid overwatering, especially in cooler months when the plant's growth slows down. A deep weekly watering during dry spells is typically sufficient to keep it healthy and productive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spondias purpurea prefers full sunlight to perform optimally. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for healthy growth and abundant fruit production. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade might help prevent leaf scorch, although the plant is fairly tolerant of high temperatures and direct sun. If planted indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure it's placed in a sunlit location, ideally a south or west-facing window. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering and fruit setting, affecting overall health and yield."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spondias purpurea involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. It's essential to use clean and sharp tools to make clean cuts. Prune to open up the canopy, which allows better air circulation and light penetration, reducing the risk of fungal infections. Controlled pruning of the plant's shape can also enhance fruit production, encouraging it to focus energy on healthy branches rather than overly dense foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red mombin","description":"Spondias purpurea is a species in flowering plant in the cashew family, Anacardiaceae, that is native to tropical regions of the Americas. It is most commonly known as jocote, which derives from the Nahuatl word xocotl, meaning any kind of sour or acidic fruit. However, this fruit can be particularly sweet when it ripens long enough. Other common names include red mombin, purple mombin, hog plum, ciruela huesito (Venezuela), ciruela, ciriguela, cirigüela, cirguela, and jobito (Ecuador).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Tropical America","Mexico","Central America","Ecuador"],"other_name":["red mombin"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spondias purpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with intense heat, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching, but full sun exposure is generally preferred for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Condalia warnockii should be done to maintain shape and remove dead or diseased branches. It's crucial to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the dry season, water the plant deeply once a week, ensuring the water penetrates several inches into the soil. Mulching around the base of the tree can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. However, be careful to avoid overhead watering as it may lead to fungal problems. Reduce watering in the rainy season and ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent water stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rambutan trees thrive in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to produce healthy and abundant fruit. The plant prefers a tropical or subtropical climate and optimal growth conditions include bright, unfiltered sun exposure. While it can tolerate some partial shade, insufficient sunlight could lead to a reduction in fruit yield and quality. Therefore, ensure that the tree is planted in an open area without overhanging structures or large trees that could cast shade over significant parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning a rambutan tree is important for maintaining its size and encouraging a healthy structure. Prune during the dry season to avoid introducing diseases. Focus on removing dead or diseased branches and shaping the tree for better air circulation and sunlight penetration. General pruning can be done to maintain the desired size, but it's important not to over-prune, as heavy cutting could affect fruit production. After the harvesting season, prune back the terminal shoot on each branch to encourage new growth, which will bear fruit in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rambutan","description":"The rambutan (/ræmˈbuːtən/, taxonomic name: Nephelium lappaceum) is a medium-sized tropical tree in the family Sapindaceae. It is closely related to several other edible tropical fruits including the lychee, longan, and mamoncillo.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Malaysia","Indonesia","Thailand"],"other_name":["Rambutan"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf roller","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Nephelium lappaceum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16427,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentiana alba, commonly known as white gentian, requires moderate watering. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once a week, adjusting frequency based on rainfall and temperature; hotter, drier conditions may necessitate more frequent watering. It's vital to avoid letting the soil completely dry out, especially during the growing season. Using mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Always water at the soil level to prevent moisture from lingering on the leaves, which can lead to fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentiana alba prefers partial to full sun conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 3-5 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, if grown in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect it from excessive heat and sunburn. In regions with milder summers, it can tolerate more direct sunlight. Ensure that the plant is not kept in full shade, as this can hinder its blooming potential. Placing it in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade is often ideal for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Gentiana alba generally requires minimal pruning. Deadheading spent flowers can promote a tidier appearance and possibly extend the flowering period. Prune in late spring or early summer, removing any dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth. Be careful not to cut back the plant too severely as this can impact its natural growth habit and blooming potential. Trim any leggy stems to maintain a compact form, but always avoid removing more than one-third of the plant at any time. Regularly observing the plant will help you determine when light pruning is necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pale gentian","description":"Gentiana alba (called plain, pale, white, cream, or yellow gentian) is a herbaceous species of flowering plant in the Gentian family Gentianaceae, producing yellowish-white colored flowers from thick white taproots. It is native to North America from Manitoba through Ontario in the north, south to Oklahoma, Arkansas and North Carolina, and it is listed as rare, endangered, threatened or extirpated in parts of this range.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["pale gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slug"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Gentiana alba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season in the warmer months, water the plant regularly to maintain slightly damp soil, allowing the top inch to dry out before re-watering. Reduce watering in the winter when the plant is dormant, ensuring the soil does not dry out completely. Be cautious of overwatering, especially if the plant is in a pot, as this can lead to root rot. Maintaining a balance is key for optimal growth and health of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hymenocallis littoralis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it ideal for areas with filtered light or morning sun. It can tolerate some full sun exposure, especially in coastal regions where the plant is native, but extreme, direct sunlight for prolonged periods can lead to leaf scorch. When grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window with sheer curtains can simulate the filtered light conditions it prefers. If grown outdoors, a location that receives dappled sunlight or partial shade during the hottest part of the day is optimal for this plant to flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Hymenocallis littoralis should be done to remove dead or damaged leaves and to prevent overcrowding. Regularly check your plant for any yellowing or dying leaves and remove them with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to encourage healthy growth. Pruning can also help manage the plant's size and shape. However, avoid cutting into healthy green leaves, as this can cause stress. After each flowering season, you can also remove spent flower stalks to tidy the plant's appearance. Always sterilize your pruning tools before and after use to prevent diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beach Spider Lily","description":"Hymenocallis littoralis or the beach spider lily is a plant species of the genus Hymenocallis, native to warmer coastal regions of Latin America and widely cultivated and naturalized in many tropical countries.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Colombia","Central America","Peru"],"other_name":["Beach Spider Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulbs"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hymenocallis littoralis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17918,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platanus rzedowskii, similar to other sycamore species, prefers a moderate watering routine. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist, particularly during the plant's active growing season in the spring and summer. It's essential to water the plant deeply, allowing the water to reach the root system, but avoid waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In autumn and winter, reduce watering to prevent over-saturation. Regularly check the soil moisture level by inserting a finger an inch or two into the soil; if it feels dry, it's time to water again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platanus rzedowskii thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers areas where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day, which supports strong growth and a healthy canopy. In hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from intense heat. However, being in too much shade can lead to sparse foliage and reduced vigor. Therefore, when planting, choose a location that balances adequate sun exposure with protection during the hottest part of the day to ensure optimal growth and foliage density."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Platanus rzedowskii is beneficial for maintaining its shape, encouraging healthy growth, and removing any dead or diseased branches. Conduct pruning during the late winter or early spring, before new growth starts. Focus on thinning crowded areas to improve air circulation within the canopy, which helps prevent disease. Remove any crossing, dead, or damaged branches, cutting them back to the point of origin or to a healthy side branch. Avoid excessive pruning, as leaving too many large wounds can stress the tree. Regular maintenance ensures the tree remains healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rzedowski's Sycamore","description":"Platanus rzedowskii, commonly known as Rzedowski's plane tree, Rzedowski's sycamore, Sicómoro de la Sierra Madre Occidental, or the Sierra Madre Occidental sycamore, is a species of Platanus in the family Platanaceae. It was described by Jackie M. Poole in 2003 with the name attributed to Kevin C. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17524,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lophophora diffusa is a cactus that requires minimal watering. Allow the soil to dry completely between watering sessions, as this plant is highly susceptible to root rot if kept too moist. Typically, watering every 2 to 4 weeks is sufficient, especially during the growing season (spring and summer). In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, possibly ceasing it altogether, as the cactus enters a dormant period. Always use well-draining soil and a pot with drainage holes to prevent water accumulation. The key is to mimic its natural desert environment, which is arid and receives infrequent rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lophophora diffusa thrives in bright light but prefers indirect sunlight or partial shade. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can scorch the plant and cause stress. If grown indoors, place it near a south or east-facing window where it can receive plenty of filtered light. In an outdoor setting, ensure it's positioned in a spot where it gets morning sun and afternoon shade. If natural light is insufficient, supplemental fluorescent lights can be used. Mimicking its natural habitat, which offers bright but diffused light, will encourage healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lophophora diffusa is generally not necessary, as it is a slow-growing cactus with a compact form. However, if you notice any dead or damaged tissue, particularly from pests or disease, it can be carefully removed to maintain plant health. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, to avoid unnecessary damage to the plant. There is no need for regular pruning since the plant's natural shape is aesthetically pleasing and its growth habit is limited. Always exercise caution and wear gloves to protect yourself from the plant's defense chemicals."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Lophophora diffusa, commonly known as false peyote, is a species of plant in the Cactaceae family and one of the only two species in the Lophophora genus. It is endemic to Mexico in the outskirts of Querétaro. This species contains zero to trace amounts of mescaline; pellotine is the principal alkaloid. The species name diffusa refers to the flat tubercles that are outspread without the plant having prominent ribs.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lophophora diffusa"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
